PricingContents.heading: Why isn't Cursor completely free?
PricingContents.ans: Large language models cost quite a bit of money to run. To grow Cursor sustainably without compromising our service quality, we need to cover our costs.

PricingContents.heading: What are fast and slow uses?
PricingContents.ans: Fast uses of premium models are given first priority by our backend. On Pro, once you hit your fast usage limit, you can still use premium models, but your requests may be queued behind others at times of high load.

PricingContents.heading: What is Cursor Tab?
PricingContents.ans: This is Cursor's native autocomplete feature. It's a more powerful Copilot that suggests entire diffs with especially good memory.

PricingContents.heading: What are the premium models?
PricingContents.ans: Examples of premium models are GPT-4, GPT-4o, and Claude 3.5/3.7 Sonnet. You have 500 fast uses and unlimited slow uses each month for these models. Some models like o3-mini use 1/3 of a fast request. The full list of premium models can be found here.

PricingContents.heading: How do the plan limits work?
PricingContents.ans: If you go over your limit, we'll nicely ask you to upgrade. You can use up to 50 uses of the premium models for free.

PricingContents.heading: Do all Cursor features work with an API key?
PricingContents.ans: A few important Cursor features (including Tab and Apply from Chat) are powered by custom models and cannot be charged to an API key.

PricingContents.heading: Who owns the code generated in Cursor?
PricingContents.ans: You! Regardless of whether you use the free, pro or business version of Cursor, all generated code is yours and free to be used however you like, including commercially.

PricingContents.heading: What code do you store?
PricingContents.ans: If you enable Privacy mode, your code is never stored anywhere other than your machine and will never be trained on. Otherwise, we may collect usage and telemetry data (including prompts, code snippets, or editor actions) to help improve Cursor.

PricingContents.heading: Where can I ask more questions?
PricingContents.ans: You‚Äôre welcome to join our forum and share your thoughts! If you prefer a private conversation, feel free to email us directly.

FeatureCards.heading: Agent
FeatureCards.description: Cursor‚Äôs agent mode can complete tasks end to end. It does this quickly, while keeping programmers in the loop. Try it out by selecting ‚Äòagent‚Äô in Composer.

small.heading: Finds Context
small.description: Using custom retrieval models, Cursor can understand a codebase. This reduces the need to manually add context.

small.heading: Runs Commands
small.description: Cursor can automatically write and run terminal commands. By default, you‚Äôll be asked to confirm all commands.

small.heading: Loops on Errors
small.description: Cursor can detect lint errors automatically and apply fixes, reducing the need for manual debugging.

FeatureCards.heading: Tab
FeatureCards.description: Cursor includes a powerful autocomplete that predicts your next edit. Once enabled, it is always on and will suggest edits to your code across multiple lines, taking into account your recent changes.

small.heading: Multi-Line Edits
small.description: Cursor can suggest multiple edits at once, saving you time.

small.heading: Smart Rewrites
small.description: Type carelessly, and Cursor will fix your mistakes.

small.heading: Cursor Prediction
small.description: Cursor predicts your next cursor position so you can seamlessly navigate your code.

FeatureCards.heading: Chat
FeatureCards.description: Chat lets you talk with an AI that sees your codebase. The chat can always see your current file and cursor, so you can ask it things like: 'Is there a bug here?'. You can add particular blocks of code to the context with Ctrl+Shift+L or @. You can chat with your entire codebase with Ctrl+Enter.

small.heading: Instant Apply
small.description: Apply the code suggestions from chat back into your codebase by clicking the play button on top of any chat codeblock.

small.heading: Codebase Answers
small.description: Use @Codebase or Ctrl Enter to ask questions about your codebase. Cursor will search your codebase to find relevant code to your query.

small.heading: Reference your Code
small.description: Reference code with @ symbols to be used as context for the AI. Just type @ to see a list of all the files and code symbols in your folder.

small.heading: Use Images
small.description: Hit the image button under chat or drag an image into the input box to include visual context into chat.

small.heading: Ask the Web
small.description: Get up-to-date information from the internet with @Web. Cursor will search the web for you and use the latest information to answer your question.

small.heading: Use Documentation
small.description: Reference popular libraries using @LibraryName, or add your own using @Docs ‚Üí Add new doc.

FeatureCards.heading: Ctrl K
FeatureCards.description: Ctrl K lets you edit and write code with the AI. To edit, try selecting some code, click Edit, and describe how the code should be changed. To generate completely new code, just type Ctrl K without selecting anything.

small.heading: Terminal Ctrl K
small.description: Use Ctrl K in the terminal to write terminal commands in plain english. Cursor will convert them into the terminal command you need.

small.heading: Quick Questions
small.description: If you have any quick questions about certain parts of your code, you can select and click on 'quick question' to get your answer right away.
